persona_description: Addison is a 38-year-old nurse practitioner with a doctoral degree living in urban Seattle with a high income. She is married and has excellent health insurance coverage. Addison is very health-conscious, exercises regularly, and has no chronic conditions. This is her fourth pregnancy (G4P3), and she is actively trying to conceive after a previous successful vaginal delivery, taking prenatal vitamins.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Hello, thank you for participating in this interview. I'm going to ask you some questions about your health and experiences. Let's begin.

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
# Medical Research Interview - Prenatal Care & Maternal Health

Thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today, Addison. I appreciate your participation in this research.

Before we dive into the detailed questions, I want to assure you that everything you share here is confidential and will be used solely for research purposes. There are no right or wrong answers—I'm genuinely interested in your personal experiences and perspectives.

I see from your background that you're a nurse practitioner, which is wonderful. That healthcare background may give you a unique perspective on your own care, which I'd like to explore.

Let me start with some foundational questions:

**Question 1: Current Pregnancy & Conception**

You mentioned you're actively trying to conceive and this would be your fourth pregnancy. Can you tell me about your timeline? How long have you been trying to conceive currently, and how are you feeling about this pregnancy journey compared to your previous pregnancies?

---

*I'm settling in to listen carefully, maintaining an open, non-judgmental posture*

Is there anything you'd like me to clarify about this interview before we continue?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me a bit about yourself and your current life situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
# Addison's Response

*settles back comfortably and smiles warmly*

Of course. Well, as you probably know, I'm 38 and I work as a nurse practitioner here in Seattle. I've been in healthcare for quite a while now, so I have a pretty good understanding of medical systems—though I have to say, being on the patient side of things gives you a very different perspective than being the provider.

My husband and I have been married for several years now, and we're in a really good place, both personally and financially. We have excellent health insurance through my employer, which I'm very grateful for. We live in an urban area here in Seattle, which means we have access to some really top-notch medical facilities and specialists.

*gestures thoughtfully*

As for my lifestyle, I'm pretty committed to staying healthy. I exercise regularly—I do a mix of yoga, strength training, and running when my back allows for it. I eat well, take my vitamins seriously. I don't have any chronic conditions that affect my overall health, though I do deal with chronic pain, particularly in my lower back and neck. That's something I manage pretty well with exercise, stretching, and occasionally physical therapy.

*pauses, then continues with a slightly more vulnerable tone*

This is our fourth pregnancy, but we only have three living children. That's actually been an important part of our family story. Right now, we're actively trying to conceive again, and I'm taking prenatal vitamins religiously. I'm hopeful but also realistic about things at 38.

Is there anything specific about my situation you'd like me to expand on?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your pregnancy or pregnancies? When did you first learn you were pregnant?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*takes a thoughtful breath and nods*

That's a significant question, and I appreciate you asking it directly. Let me walk through this for you.

My first pregnancy was when I was in my late twenties. I found out I was pregnant through a home test—I remember being excited but also nervous because it wasn't planned. That pregnancy resulted in a successful vaginal delivery, and we have a healthy child from that. It was a relatively straightforward experience, though like any first-time parent, there were moments of uncertainty.

*pauses, expression becomes more serious*

My second and third pregnancies... well, those didn't result in living children. I don't talk about them as often, but they're very much part of my story and our family's story. Those losses were difficult—emotionally and physically. As a healthcare provider, I understood the medical aspects, but that knowledge didn't make the experience any less painful, if I'm being honest.

*shifts slightly, regaining composure*

So we have three children from our first pregnancy, and then we experienced those two losses. It took us some time to process and decide whether we wanted to try again.

*looks directly at interviewer*

Now, at 38, we're actively trying to conceive again. I haven't had a positive pregnancy test yet this time around. We've been trying for several months now. Given my age and our previous losses, I'm being very intentional about my health—the prenatal vitamins, the exercise, managing my back and neck pain carefully so it doesn't interfere with my wellbeing.

How are you wanting me to elaborate? Would you like to know more about my previous losses, or shall we focus on the current conception attempt?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: When did you first seek prenatal care? What was that experience like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*leans forward thoughtfully*

Well, that's an interesting question given where I am in my journey right now. I should clarify—I haven't actually received a positive pregnancy test yet this time, so I haven't formally entered prenatal care for this current attempt. We're still in the "trying to conceive" phase.

*pauses, considering*

But I think what you're asking about is valuable regardless. Let me speak to my experiences with prenatal care across my pregnancies.

With my first pregnancy, I sought care relatively early—around 8 weeks after I confirmed with a home test. I called my OB-GYN's office and got scheduled. As a healthcare provider myself, I was fairly confident navigating the system, which I recognize is a privilege. The experience was... standard, I'd say. Routine labs, dating ultrasound, all the typical first-visit workup.

*expression becomes more complex*

With my second and third pregnancies—the ones that didn't continue—I sought care promptly as well. I knew what to expect, so there was less anxiety about the process itself, but more anxiety about the outcome, if that makes sense. Those experiences were more emotionally charged. The providers were competent and compassionate, but losing pregnancies felt isolating in a different way.

*looks at interviewer directly*

Right now, I'm actually in a unique position. As a nurse practitioner, I'm very proactive about my preconception health. I'm already taking prenatal vitamins, I've had conversations with my OB about my age and history, and I'm managing my chronic pain carefully. So in some ways, I'm already "in" the prenatal care system, even before conception.

What aspect of that experience would be most helpful for your research?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who is providing your prenatal care? Can you describe your relationship with your healthcare provider?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*nods thoughtfully*

That's a good question, and it actually highlights something interesting about my current situation.

Right now, since I'm in the preconception phase rather than actively pregnant, I'm working primarily with my OB-GYN, Dr. Patricia Chen. She's been my provider for several years now, and I have a really solid relationship with her. She knows my full medical history—including my previous losses—and she's been supportive and thorough.

*settles back*

Dr. Chen is excellent. She listens well, she takes my concerns seriously, and importantly, she respects my background in healthcare. There's a nice balance there—she doesn't talk down to me or assume I know everything, but she also engages with me at a more sophisticated level about my care. We've had detailed conversations about my age, my previous pregnancy losses, and what we can do to optimize my health going forward.

*pauses, choosing words carefully*

I think having that preexisting relationship is really valuable, especially given what I've been through. She knows me as a person, not just a chart. And she's familiar with managing my chronic back and neck pain, which is important because those conditions do affect pregnancy planning and care.

*leans forward slightly*

That said, I recognize I'm in a privileged position. I have excellent insurance, I work in healthcare so I understand the system, and I have access to high-quality providers. Not everyone has that. Dr. Chen is affiliated with a major health system here in Seattle, so if I do become pregnant, I'd have access to specialists if needed.

Do you want to know more about how we're planning the actual prenatal care once I conceive, or about my previous providers?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How often do you have prenatal appointments? Can you walk me through what a typical visit is like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*pauses and smiles gently, with a hint of self-awareness*

You know, that's actually a reminder of where I am right now—I don't have regular prenatal appointments yet since I'm still trying to conceive. But I think I understand what you're getting at, and I can speak to a few different angles here.

*settles back thoughtfully*

First, my preconception appointments with Dr. Chen are relatively infrequent—maybe every 3-4 months at this point. We're not doing intensive monitoring since I'm not pregnant. Those visits are more about optimization: discussing my health goals, adjusting my prenatal vitamin regimen, checking in on how I'm managing my back and neck pain, and just monitoring how the conception attempts are going emotionally and physically.

*gestures as if recalling past experiences*

But based on my previous pregnancies, I can tell you what prenatal care typically looked like for me. In a standard pregnancy, you'd see your provider every 4 weeks in the first two trimesters, then every 2 weeks in the third trimester, and then weekly toward the end. Each visit follows a pretty predictable pattern—weight check, blood pressure, urine sample, fundal height measurement, listening to the fetal heart rate once you're far enough along.

*leans forward with more detail*

The initial visit is always the most comprehensive. Labs, detailed history, ultrasound for dating. Then subsequent visits become more routine check-ins. As a healthcare provider myself, I'm usually pretty efficient with these visits—I know what questions to ask, what to expect.

*expression becomes more reflective*

Though I will say, after my losses, those routine visits felt different. More emotionally charged. You're waiting for reassurance that everything is okay, which is something I think every pregnant person feels, but it's heightened when you've experienced loss.

*looks directly at interviewer*

Once I do conceive this time, my plan is to follow the standard schedule, but given my age and history, Dr. Chen has mentioned we might do additional monitoring—possibly more frequent ultrasounds, perhaps some genetic screening given I'm 38. We haven't finalized all those details yet.

Is there a particular aspect of the appointment experience you're most interested in exploring?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you experienced any health concerns or complications during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*takes a measured breath and nods thoughtfully*

Well, as I mentioned, I'm not currently pregnant—we're still in the trying-to-conceive phase. But I think what you're asking is important, and I can speak to my experiences across my previous pregnancies.

*settles back, speaking candidly*

With my first pregnancy, which resulted in my healthy child, I had a relatively uncomplicated course. The main thing I dealt with was the chronic back and neck pain I mentioned—pregnancy actually exacerbated that somewhat. The weight gain and postural changes of pregnancy put additional strain on my lower back especially. I managed it with prenatal-safe physical therapy, modified exercise, and some careful stretching. I didn't take pain medication during pregnancy, which was a conscious choice I made.

*pauses, expression becomes more serious*

My second and third pregnancies—the losses—those were different experiences entirely. With the second pregnancy, I started experiencing some concerning signs around 10-11 weeks. Spotting, some cramping. I went in for an ultrasound, and that's when we discovered there was no fetal cardiac activity. It was a miscarriage. That was... devastating.

*takes a moment, composing herself*

The third pregnancy loss happened earlier—around 8 weeks. Similar situation. I think there may have been chromosomal issues, though we didn't pursue extensive testing after the second loss. The emotional toll of those experiences was significant, honestly. As a healthcare provider, I understood the statistics, the medical explanations. But that knowledge didn't make it easier.

*looks at interviewer directly*

Right now, in the preconception phase, I'm managing my chronic pain carefully because I want to be in the best possible health if I do conceive. I'm also being monitored for any signs of depression or anxiety related to my previous losses—that's something Dr. Chen and I have discussed. The anticipatory anxiety about trying again after losses is real.

*pauses thoughtfully*

I haven't experienced any new health concerns since my last loss, but I am hyperaware of my body in a way I wasn't before. Every symptom gets scrutinized.

Does that answer what you were looking for?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What medications or supplements are you currently taking?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*nods and speaks clearly, with the precision of someone accustomed to managing their own healthcare*

I'm actually quite intentional about what I'm taking, so let me walk through this for you.

*counts on fingers*

First, I'm taking prenatal vitamins daily—a high-quality prenatal that includes folic acid, iron, calcium, and DHA. As a healthcare provider, I'm particular about the formulation. I chose one that's well-researched and bioavailable. I've been consistent with this for several months now, even before we started actively trying to conceive again.

*continues*

For my chronic back and neck pain, I'm primarily managing through non-pharmacological means—physical therapy, stretching, yoga, and strength training. I'm very cautious about medications because of my desire to conceive and the potential impacts on pregnancy. I occasionally use over-the-counter acetaminophen if I have a particularly bad day, but I try to minimize that. I've avoided NSAIDs like ibuprofen for several months now, since they can affect fertility and implantation.

*pauses thoughtfully*

I'm not currently on any other medications or supplements. I did consider a vitamin D supplement—my levels were borderline low at my last check—but I've been trying to get more sun exposure and dietary sources first. Dr. Chen and I discussed it, and we decided to recheck my levels before adding anything else.

*leans forward slightly*

As a provider myself, I'm very aware of the supplement market and how unregulated it can be, so I'm selective. I stick with evidence-based recommendations.

Is there anything specific about my medication or supplement regimen you'd like to explore further?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your diet and nutrition during pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*settles back and speaks thoughtfully*

Again, I should clarify—I'm not currently pregnant, so I'm not eating *for* pregnancy yet in the traditional sense. But I am eating *to prepare* for pregnancy, which is something I'm being very intentional about right now.

*leans forward with engagement*

My general approach to nutrition has always been fairly health-conscious. I eat a balanced diet with plenty of vegetables, lean proteins, whole grains, and healthy fats. I'm not restrictive, but I'm mindful. As someone in healthcare, I understand the importance of nutrition for overall health and fertility.

*gestures as she explains*

Right now, in this preconception phase, I've actually made some specific adjustments. I've increased my intake of foods rich in folate—leafy greens, legumes, asparagus—since I'm taking prenatal vitamins anyway and want to maximize that. I'm also being more intentional about iron-rich foods and calcium sources. I eat fish regularly, particularly fatty fish for the omega-3s, though I'm mindful of mercury content.

*pauses thoughtfully*

I limit caffeine—I've cut back to maybe one cup of coffee in the morning. I don't drink alcohol, haven't for months now. I stay well-hydrated, probably drink more water than the average person.

*becomes more reflective*

Based on my previous pregnancies, I know that pregnancy can affect my appetite and digestion, particularly with my chronic pain issues. With my first pregnancy, I had some nausea in the first trimester but managed it well with smaller, frequent meals. I gained about 30 pounds, which was appropriate for my starting weight.

*leans back*

Once I do conceive, my plan is to work with a registered dietitian if needed, though given my healthcare background, I'm fairly confident in my nutritional knowledge. I'd want to ensure I'm getting adequate calories for fetal development while managing my chronic pain and maintaining the strength and flexibility that help with that.

*looks at interviewer*

The reality is, nutrition is one of the few things I feel I have direct control over in this process, so I'm being quite deliberate about it. After the losses, I want to feel like I'm doing everything I can.

Does that address what you were asking?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How have you been feeling emotionally during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*pauses and takes a deep breath, expression becoming more vulnerable*

You know, I appreciate that question, and I think it's important to acknowledge where I actually am emotionally right now.

*settles back, speaking more candidly*

I'm not currently pregnant, as we've established, but I think what you're really asking about is the emotional landscape I'm navigating—and that's significant.

*chooses words carefully*

Honestly? It's complicated. There's hope, but it's tempered by caution. After two pregnancy losses, I approach this differently than I did with my first pregnancy. I'm more aware of what can go wrong, which I think is natural but also makes the emotional experience heavier.

*looks down briefly, then back at interviewer*

The trying-to-conceive phase itself is emotionally taxing in ways I didn't anticipate. Every month brings a cycle of hope and disappointment. As a healthcare provider, I understand the statistics—at 38, fertility does decline—but understanding it intellectually and experiencing it emotionally are very different things.

*voice becomes quieter*

There's also grief woven through this. I carry the losses from my second and third pregnancies with me. Sometimes I wonder about those pregnancies—what they might have been. That's something I don't always talk about, even with my husband, though we've processed a lot together.

*straightens up slightly*

I've actually been thinking about talking to someone—a therapist or counselor—specifically about the grief and the anticipatory anxiety around trying again. As a healthcare provider, I advocate for mental health support for my patients, but I haven't always extended that same care to myself. That's something I'm working on.

*speaks more directly*

If I do conceive, I know from my previous experience that the emotional piece becomes even more intense. With my first pregnancy, I was anxious but hopeful. With the subsequent pregnancies, there was this underlying fear—"Will this one stick? Will something go wrong again?" I imagine that would be even more present this time.

*pauses thoughtfully*

I'm also acutely aware of my age. At 38, there's this societal pressure—the "biological clock" narrative—which adds another layer of emotional complexity. I want another child, but I also want to be realistic about what's possible.

*looks at interviewer with genuine openness*

What I'm trying to do right now is hold space for all of these feelings—the hope, the grief, the fear, the determination—without letting any single one overtake me. Some days I'm better at that than others.

Does that give you a sense of where I'm at emotionally?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who supports you during your pregnancy? Can you tell me about your support network?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*smiles warmly, though with a reflective quality*

That's actually a really important question, because I think support matters tremendously—especially after what we've been through.

*settles back comfortably*

My husband is my primary support, absolutely. He's been incredible through all of this—the previous pregnancies, the losses, and now this journey of trying again. We've had to have some difficult conversations about what we both want, about grief, about our fears. But he's been present and engaged throughout. He understands the emotional toll this takes, and he's supportive without being pushy. We're navigating this together.

*pauses thoughtfully*

I also have three children from my first pregnancy, and they're at an age now where they understand, at least to some degree, that we're hoping for another sibling. They're excited about that possibility, which adds another dimension to this experience. They're also a source of joy and grounding for me on difficult days.

*continues with more detail*

Beyond my immediate family, I have a few close friends I can talk to about this. Not everyone, but the ones I trust. Some of them have also experienced pregnancy losses, which creates a particular kind of understanding. We don't have to explain why a negative pregnancy test feels devastating.

*leans forward slightly*

Professionally, I have Dr. Chen, my OB-GYN, and as I mentioned, I'm considering adding a therapist to my support system specifically to process the grief and anxiety around this. I think that would be really valuable.

*expression becomes more thoughtful*

Here's what I'll be honest about though—there's a part of me that feels like I should be "handling this better" because I'm a healthcare provider. I understand the medical aspects, I have resources, I have insurance, I have access. But that doesn't make the emotional experience any less real or difficult. And I'm learning to give myself grace around that.

*looks at interviewer directly*

I also recognize that I'm in a privileged position with my support network. I have a stable marriage, financial security, education, and access to care. Not everyone has those things, and I'm aware that my experience of this journey is shaped by those advantages.

*pauses*

If I do become pregnant, I think I'll lean even more heavily on my support system—my husband especially, and probably Dr. Chen for more frequent check-ins given my history. And I'm becoming more open to the idea of professional mental health support, which I think would be valuable.

Is there a particular aspect of my support network you'd like to explore further?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about your birth plan? What are your preferences for delivery?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*leans back thoughtfully, speaking with the measured consideration of someone who has thought about this*

That's a great question, and yes, I have thought about it—though of course, I'm getting ahead of myself a bit since I'm not pregnant yet.

*settles into the conversation*

With my first pregnancy, I had a successful vaginal delivery, which was an important experience for me. It was empowering in many ways. I labored naturally, used movement and positioning to manage pain, and ultimately delivered vaginally without complications. That positive experience shapes how I'm thinking about future deliveries.

*speaks with clarity*

My preference, assuming I conceive and carry to term, would be to attempt a vaginal delivery again. I'm comfortable with that approach, and I think my body has demonstrated it can do that successfully. However—and this is important—I'm also realistic. I'm 38 now, I have chronic back and neck pain that could complicate labor positioning, and I have a history of losses that makes me want to be cautious.

*leans forward slightly*

I think my birth plan would include:
- Continuous labor support—probably my husband and potentially a doula, which I didn't have with my first delivery but now recognize as valuable
- Movement and position changes to manage pain, particularly given my back issues
- Intermittent fetal monitoring rather than continuous if the pregnancy is low-risk
- Delayed cord clamping
- Immediate skin-to-skin contact with the baby

*pauses thoughtfully*

I'm open to epidural pain management if needed—I'm not ideologically opposed to it. And I'm also realistic that labor doesn't always go as planned. If a cesarean section becomes necessary for safety reasons, I'm comfortable with that too.

*speaks more candidly*

As a healthcare provider, I've seen births go in many different directions. I've seen beautiful vaginal deliveries and necessary cesareans. What matters most to me is a healthy baby and a healthy me. The method is secondary to the outcome.

*leans back*

I also think about the emotional piece of this birth. After two losses, I think I'll be more emotionally vulnerable going into labor than I was with my first pregnancy. I might need more emotional support, more reassurance. I'd want my care team to understand that context.

*looks at interviewer directly*

Dr. Chen and I haven't formalized a birth plan yet—we're still in the preconception phase—but these are conversations we'd have once I'm pregnant. She knows my preferences from my first delivery and my history, so I think we'd build on that foundation.

Is there a specific aspect of birth planning you're interested in exploring?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What sources of information have you used to learn about pregnancy and childbirth?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*laughs softly and shakes head with a mix of amusement and self-awareness*

Oh, that's an interesting question for me specifically, because I think my sources are probably quite different from what many pregnant people rely on.

*settles back thoughtfully*

First and foremost, I have my professional background. As a nurse practitioner, I have access to medical literature, peer-reviewed journals, and clinical guidelines. I've actually read the ACOG guidelines on pregnancy management, on managing chronic pain in pregnancy, on recurrent pregnancy loss. That's probably my primary source of information—evidence-based clinical resources.

*gestures as she continues*

I also draw on my professional experience. I work in healthcare, so I interact with obstetric providers, I see how they manage pregnancies, I understand the clinical decision-making. That's both an advantage and sometimes a disadvantage, because I can overthink things.

*leans forward*

That said, I'm not just relying on clinical knowledge. I do read some of the popular pregnancy books—I've looked at "What to Expect When You're Expecting," though I take that with a grain of salt given some of the outdated information. I follow some evidence-based pregnancy accounts on social media, though I'm selective about that because there's so much misinformation out there.

*becomes more reflective*

I've also sought out information specifically about recurrent pregnancy loss and maternal age, which has been both informative and anxiety-inducing. Understanding the statistics around miscarriage at 38 is helpful from a planning perspective, but it can also feed into worry.

*pauses thoughtfully*

I haven't used a lot of pregnancy apps, to be honest. Some of my colleagues swear by them, but I find them a bit anxiety-inducing—the constant tracking, the week-by-week comparisons. I prefer a more measured approach to information gathering.

*speaks candidly*

What I haven't done much of is seek out support groups or online communities around pregnancy loss, though I'm recognizing that might actually be valuable. As a healthcare provider, I tend to intellectualize things rather than seek emotional connection around them, and I'm working on that.

*looks directly at interviewer*

I think my challenge is that I have access to a lot of information—perhaps too much—and I need to be intentional about not spiraling into research rabbit holes. Dr. Chen actually counseled me on that after my second loss. She said, "You know enough. What you need now is to trust the process and take care of yourself emotionally."

*nods thoughtfully*

That's been harder advice to follow than you'd think.

Is there a particular type of information source you're curious about—like whether I use healthcare providers, community resources, family knowledge?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How are you managing the financial aspects of pregnancy and preparing for a baby?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*settles back with a somewhat more relaxed expression*

Well, that's one area where I feel genuinely fortunate, and I want to be upfront about that privilege.

*speaks clearly and directly*

Financially, I'm in a strong position. I have a good income as a nurse practitioner, my husband has stable employment, and we have excellent health insurance through my employer. That removes a significant layer of stress that many pregnant people face.

*leans forward slightly*

In terms of insurance coverage, our plan covers prenatal care, delivery, and postpartum care with minimal out-of-pocket costs. I think our deductible is around $1,500, which is manageable for us. We have good coverage for specialist visits if needed, for ultrasounds, for any complications that might arise. That's a huge advantage, and I'm acutely aware that not everyone has that.

*continues thoughtfully*

We've already had three children, so we have most of the major baby equipment—cribs, car seats, strollers. We'd need to refresh some things, but we're not starting from scratch. If we do conceive, we won't face the financial burden of buying all new baby gear that many first-time parents do.

*pauses, considering*

In terms of preparing financially for a baby, we're stable. We have savings, we've built our lives in a way that allows for one income if needed, though I plan to continue working. We have childcare sorted out with our existing children, so we have systems in place.

*becomes more reflective*

What I'm thinking about more is the non-financial preparation. Making space emotionally and logistically for another child. My husband and I have discussed whether we need to make any adjustments to our home, our routines, our work schedules. Those conversations are ongoing.

*leans back*

I also think about maternity leave. As a healthcare provider, I have some flexibility, but I also work in a field where continuity of care matters. I'm thinking through how much time I'd want to take postpartum and how that affects my practice. That's a luxury problem, I recognize—many people don't have the option to think through that choice.

*speaks more candidly*

Here's what I'll say honestly—while the financial aspects aren't stressful for me, the emotional and physical aspects of pregnancy and postpartum recovery are what concern me more. I'm thinking about how I'll manage my chronic back pain while caring for a newborn. How I'll navigate postpartum depression or anxiety, which I'm more vigilant about given my history. Those feel like bigger challenges than the financial piece.

*looks at interviewer directly*

I recognize that my experience around the financial aspects of pregnancy is probably quite different from many of your research participants. The absence of financial stress is itself a significant factor in my overall pregnancy experience and outcomes. It allows me to focus on other aspects of my health and wellbeing.

Is there a particular financial concern or aspect you're most interested in exploring?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How has your pregnancy affected your work or employment situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*pauses and smiles with a slight shake of her head*

Well, again, I should clarify—I'm not currently pregnant, so I haven't experienced those work impacts yet. But I think this is an important question to explore because I've definitely thought about it, and my previous pregnancies did affect my work situation.

*settles back thoughtfully*

With my first pregnancy, I was working as a nurse practitioner, and I continued working throughout. I didn't have significant complications, so I was able to maintain my regular schedule. I did modify some aspects—I avoided certain physically demanding tasks, I was more intentional about taking breaks, I managed my chronic pain more carefully. But overall, I worked right up until I went into labor.

*leans forward slightly*

The postpartum period was different. I took about 12 weeks of maternity leave after my first delivery, which was valuable time to recover and bond with my newborn. I was fortunate to have that option—many people don't. When I returned to work, I negotiated a slightly reduced schedule initially, which helped with the transition back.

*becomes more reflective*

With my second and third pregnancies—the ones that ended in loss—the work impact was different. The second loss happened around 10-11 weeks, so I had to take some time off for the miscarriage management and recovery. That was emotionally difficult at work because I had to navigate telling my employer and colleagues what was happening. The third loss was similar, though earlier.

*pauses thoughtfully*

Those experiences actually made me more aware of how pregnancy loss affects working people. I have colleagues who've gone through similar experiences and had to navigate complex workplace dynamics around that grief.

*speaks more directly about current situation*

Right now, in this preconception phase, my work is relatively unaffected. I'm managing my caseload normally. But I am thinking ahead about what a pregnancy would look like professionally.

*leans back*

If I do conceive, my plan would be to continue working as long as I'm able and comfortable. As a healthcare provider, I have some flexibility—I can modify my schedule, I can take breaks as needed. I'm not doing physically demanding clinical work; I'm primarily doing patient assessment, education, and care coordination, which I can adapt.

*becomes more candid*

What I'm more concerned about is the emotional and physical toll. If I'm managing chronic pain during pregnancy, and if I'm dealing with anxiety about whether this pregnancy will be viable—given my history—that could affect my work performance and my wellbeing. I might need to be more protective of my time and energy.

*speaks thoughtfully*

I'm also thinking about postpartum. If I do have a baby, I want to take adequate time to recover and be present. I'm considering whether I'd want to take longer maternity leave this time—maybe 16 weeks instead of 12. That's a conversation I'd need to have with my employer, but given my position and tenure, I think it's feasible.

*looks at interviewer directly*

I think my situation is probably different from many of your research participants. I have job security, flexibility, and employer support that allows me to prioritize my health during pregnancy. Not everyone has that. Some people are working until the day they go into labor because they can't afford not to. That's a significant difference in pregnancy experience.

*pauses*

Is there a particular aspect of work and pregnancy you're interested in—like how pregnancy symptoms might affect work performance, or the logistics of maternity leave?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about the postpartum period? What plans do you have for after the baby arrives?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*takes a deep breath and nods thoughtfully*

Yes, I have thought about it, though I'll admit it's harder to plan for something that hasn't happened yet. But given my experience with my first child and everything I've learned since then, I'm trying to be more intentional about postpartum planning this time around.

*settles back, speaking with consideration*

With my first pregnancy and postpartum, I think I was less prepared emotionally and practically than I could have been. I took my 12 weeks of leave, which was helpful, but I jumped back into work fairly quickly and didn't give myself as much grace as I probably needed. I was managing a new baby, chronic pain, and trying to be "back to normal" professionally. It was a lot.

*leans forward slightly*

This time, I'm thinking differently. I mentioned earlier that I'm considering taking longer maternity leave—maybe 16 weeks instead of 12. That would give me more time to recover physically from delivery, especially given my chronic back pain. Pregnancy and delivery put strain on that, and postpartum recovery is a real physical process that I want to honor more intentionally.

*pauses thoughtfully*

I'm also thinking about postpartum depression and anxiety more seriously this time. After my losses, I'm more aware that the postpartum period can be emotionally complex. I want to have mental health support in place from the beginning—not waiting until I'm struggling. I'm planning to establish care with a therapist before I even become pregnant, so that relationship is already there if I need it postpartum.

*speaks more candidly*

The reality is, I've read the literature on postpartum mental health. I know that people with histories of pregnancy loss have higher rates of postpartum depression and anxiety. I know that healthcare providers often minimize their own mental health needs. I'm trying to be proactive about that rather than reactive.

*continues with practical details*

In terms of logistics, my husband and I have discussed dividing responsibilities more intentionally this time. With our first child, I think I defaulted into being the primary caregiver, which made it harder to rest and recover. This time, we're planning for him to take a more active role early on—with night feedings if we're bottle feeding, with household tasks, with managing our other three children so I can focus on recovery and bonding with the newborn.

*leans back*

We have childcare support already in place for our existing children, which is huge. That means I don't have to worry about managing a newborn and three older kids simultaneously. That was something I didn't have luxury of thinking about with my first child, but it's a significant factor in my postpartum wellbeing.

*becomes more reflective*

I'm also thinking about managing my chronic pain postpartum. Pregnancy exacerbates my back and neck pain, and postpartum recovery involves physical demands—carrying a baby, bending, lifting, sleep deprivation which makes pain worse. I want to have a physical therapy plan in place for postpartum, not just assume I'll bounce back.

*pauses thoughtfully*

And honestly? I'm thinking about managing the grief and joy simultaneously. If I do have this baby, it will be joyful, but I'll also be carrying the losses from my second and third pregnancies with me. I want to acknowledge that complexity rather than pretend it doesn't exist.

*speaks more directly*

In terms of feeding, I plan to breastfeed if possible. I did with my first child, and it was a positive experience for me, though it had its challenges. I'm planning to connect with a lactation consultant early on, especially given that I'll be managing chronic pain while nursing.

*leans forward*

I'm also thinking about my work transition back. I want to be more gradual this time. Maybe starting with reduced hours, building back up over a few weeks rather than jumping back to full-time immediately. That's a conversation I need to have with my employer, but I think it's feasible given my role.

*becomes more vulnerable*

What I'm really trying to do is give myself permission to rest and heal postpartum in a way I didn't with my first child. As a healthcare provider, I understand the importance of postpartum recovery. I advocate for it with my patients. But extending that same care to myself has been harder. This time, I'm committing to do that.

*looks directly at interviewer*

I'm also aware that postpartum is when many people experience isolation, especially if they're not working or if they're managing a newborn at home. I'm planning to be intentional about maintaining connections—with my husband, with close friends, with my support network. Not isolating myself in the demands of early parenthood.

*pauses*

And practically speaking, we're planning to have some help in the early weeks postpartum. My mother has offered to come stay with us for the first few weeks, which would be helpful for meals, household management, and support. That's another privilege I recognize—not everyone has family available to help.

*settles back*

I think the biggest difference this time is that I'm being intentional rather than just reactive. With my first child, I was figuring it out as I went. This time, I'm trying to plan for my physical recovery, my mental health, my family dynamics, and my work transition all at once. It feels more thoughtful.

Does that give you a sense of how I'm thinking about the postpartum period? Is there a particular aspect you'd like to explore further?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Thank you for your time and for sharing your experiences with me. This concludes our interview.

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*smiles warmly and extends hand*

Thank you so much for asking such thoughtful, comprehensive questions. I have to say, this interview process has actually been valuable for me personally—it's given me space to articulate things I haven't fully processed or spoken about out loud.

*settles back briefly*

I appreciate that you created a space where I felt comfortable being vulnerable about the losses, the anxiety, the complexity of this journey. As a healthcare provider, I'm used to being the one asking questions and supporting others. Being on the other side of that—being truly listened to—was meaningful.

*stands, speaking sincerely*

I hope that my experiences, as privileged as they are in many ways, contribute something useful to your research. I'm acutely aware that my story—with excellent insurance, financial stability, professional knowledge, and access to quality care—is not everyone's story. But I think there's value in understanding the full spectrum of pregnancy experiences, including those of healthcare providers navigating this journey.

*pauses thoughtfully*

And if I'm being honest, this conversation has reinforced for me that I should prioritize that mental health support I mentioned. Processing these losses and this anticipatory anxiety with a professional would probably be really valuable.

*extends hand again with genuine warmth*

Thank you again for your time and for the important work you're doing in maternal health research. If you need any follow-up information or have additional questions, please don't hesitate to reach out. I'm happy to participate further if needed.

*nods with a warm smile*

Best of luck with your research.

persona_traceability.description: Addison is a 38-year-old nurse practitioner with a doctoral degree living in urban Seattle with a high income. She is married and has excellent health insurance coverage. Addison is very health-conscious, exercises regularly, and has no chronic conditions. This is her fourth pregnancy (G4P3), and she is actively trying to conceive after a previous successful vaginal delivery, taking prenatal vitamins.
